{{Expand list|date=August 2008}} [[Image:I-45 & Louetta Rita Evacuation.jpg|thumb|Evacuees fleeing [[Hurricane Rita]] in Texas, United States]]
This '''list of mass evacuations''' includes [[emergency evacuation]]s of a large number of people in a short period of time. An emergency evacuation is the movement of persons from a dangerous place due to the threat or occurrence of a disastrous event whether from [[Natural disaster|natural]] or [[Man-made hazards|man made]] causes or as the result of [[war]].
==Ancient times== * 480 BC – The [[Greece|Greek]] officer of state and navy commander [[Themistocles]] ordered the evacuation of [[Athens]] as a strategic countermeasure to the approaching [[Achaemenid Empire|Persian]] army, leading to 100,000 inhabitants being displaced in the late summer.
==1st century== * 60–61 – [[Boudica's uprising]] results in the mass evacuation of numerous [[Ancient Rome|Roman]] settlements in [[Great Britain|Britain]]. * 79 – Eruption of [[Mount Vesuvius]] causes evacuation of [[Pompeii]] and surrounding areas.
==5th century== * 410 – [[Sack of Rome (410)|Sack of Rome]] by [[Visigoths]] under [[Alaric I]]. Many [[Rome, Italy|Romans]] were either taken captive and sold into slavery or later fled the devastated city.
==13th century== * 1237–1293 – [[Mongol invasion of Europe]]: Many thousands in eastern [[Europe]] are displaced or flee before each of several Mongol expeditions.
==14th century== * 1351 – Peak of the [[Black Death]], which [[Consequences of the Black Death|led to mass evacuations]] in numerous cities, ports, and villages in Asia, Europe, and [[Egypt]].
==19th century== * 1836 – The [[Battle of the Alamo|Fall of the Alamo]] results in a mass evacuation of American, [[Mexico|Mexican]], [[Tejano]], and [[Texian]] persons in what is known as the [[Runaway Scrape]].
==20th century== [[File:Evacuees from Mount Pinatubo board the USS Abraham Lincoln.jpg|thumb|U.S. military dependents board {{USS|Abraham Lincoln|CVN-72}} in the aftermath of the [[Mount Pinatubo#The 1991 eruption|1991 eruption of Mount Pinatubo]].]] * April 20, 1906 – The resultant fire of the [[1906 San Francisco earthquake]] leads to evacuation by sea of 20,000 refugees.<ref>{{cite web|title=Timeline of the San Francisco Earthquake|publisher=The Virtual Museum of the City of San Francisco|url=http://www.sfmuseum.org/hist10/06timeline.html|accessdate=2007-10-25 }}</ref> * Between March 1937 and October 1938, nearly 3,000 children were evacuated from [[Spain]] to the [[Soviet Union]]. Most of the children were from the [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque Country]], [[Asturias]], and [[Cantabria]]. On June 12, 1937 over 1,500 children and 75 tutors (teachers, doctors, and nurses) left the Port of [[Santurtzi]] in the [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque]] province of [[Bizkaia]] on board the ship "Habana." Similarly, nearly 4,000 children were evacuated to the United Kingdom, also on the "Habana", with the [[HMS Hood (51)|HMS Hood]] as an escort. They became, and are still known as, "los niños de la guerra" ("the war children") or the "Gernika Generation" (as regards Basques). * September 1939 – The [[evacuations of civilians in Britain during World War II]]; at the outset of [[World War II]], [[London]] and major [[Great Britain|British]] cities were evacuated, with 1.5 million displaced in the first three days of the official evacuation. The final number of evacuees reached 3.75 million. * 1939–1940 and June 1944 – The entire population of [[Finland|Finnish]] [[Karelia]], 522,000 people, was [[Evacuation of Finnish Karelia|evacuated]] during the [[Winter War]]. Some 260,000 of these returned home during the [[Continuation War]], but were evacuated again in June 1944. * May–June 1940 – [[Operation Dynamo]] was implemented, with around 439,000 British and French troops evacuated from [[Dunkirk, France]].<ref name="youtube">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=18lsxFcDrjo</ref> * 20–23 June 1940 – 24,600 people, a third of the population, are evacuated from the [[Channel Islands]] to [[England]] and [[Scotland]] ahead of the [[Occupation of the Channel Islands#Invasion|German invasion]]. * October 1940 – 1945 – [[Evacuations of children in Germany during World War II]] * October 1941 – A mass evacuation of [[Moscow]] was ordered in the face of the threat of the war estimated 1.5 million to 3 million [[Germany|German]] [[Wehrmacht]]. Two million inhabitants were displaced within two weeks. *1942 – 1945 – Evacuation and deportation of [[Ingrian Finns]] from [[Ingria]] during and after World War II. About the entire population of Ingrian Finns (estimating 70,000 people) was evacuated from [[Leningrad Oblast|Leningrad oblast]], [[Russia]] to [[Estonia]] and [[Finland]]. Those who returned after the war faced deportations to other parts of Russia. * Autumn 1944-Spring 1945 – [[Evacuation of East Prussia]] (1.8 million people) and [[Pomerania]] (various estimates range between 3 and 7 million; see [[Flight and expulsion of Germans from Poland during and after World War II]]) * June 1944 – August 1945 – [[Evacuations of civilians in Japan during World War II]] * 1945–1951 – [[Istrian exodus]] From the end of World War II through 1953, according to various data, between 250,000 and 350,000 people emigrated from these regions * May 1950 – One hundred thousand people were evacuated from [[Winnipeg]], [[Manitoba]], Canada during the devastating [[Red River of the North|Red River]] flood of 1950.<ref>{{cite news|title=A City Submerged – Winnipeg and the Flood of 1950 – CBC Archives|publisher=[[CBC News|CBC]]|url=http://archives.cbc.ca/environment/extreme_weather/clips/3783/|accessdate=2009-02-22 }}</ref> * Between December 10 and 24, 1950, over 100,000 [[United Nations|UN]] troops who were cut off by the [[China|Chinese]] intervention forces in Northern Korea, along with an even larger number of civilian refugees, were evacuated from the [[North Korea]]n port of [[Hungnam]] during the [[Korean War]]. * July–August 1971 – 18 million people migrated from [[Bangladesh]] (then known as [[East Pakistan]]) to [[India]] to escape the military forces of [[Pakistan]] (then known as [[West Pakistan]]). This was the largest and bloodiest exodus in human history, with 4 million dead. * 26–31 December 1974 – As a result of [[Cyclone Tracy]] destroying over 85 percent of the city, more than 60,000 people from [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin, Australia]] are evacuated from the area, leaving just 10,000 people (mainly adult males) to begin the massive cleanup. * July 1974 – The complete, spontaneous evacuation in a few hours of [[Varosha (Famagusta)#1974 to present day|Varosha]] before the advancing [[Turkey|Turkish]] army; the population feared a [[massacre]]. * 1975 – [[Operation Frequent Wind]]: thousands of [[South Vietnam]]ese and the last remaining Americans evacuate [[Ho Chi Minh City|Saigon]], capital of [[South Vietnam]], before the invading [[Vietcong]] and [[Vietnam People's Army|North Vietnamese Army]] overrun the city. * July to October 1975 – After the end of the [[Portuguese colonial war]], one million [[Portugal|Portuguese]] civilians were flown from former Portuguese colonies in Africa, mainly [[Angola]] and [[Mozambique]], back to Portugal. Thousands of flights were organized by the [[Government of Portugal|Portuguese government]], using hundreds of commercial [[airplane]]s. * 1975–1979 – [[Cambodia]]: After the [[Khmer Rouge]] take over the capital of [[Phnom Penh]], all civilians are forced to [[Khmer Rouge rule of Cambodia#Evacuation of the cities|evacuate the cities]] for the countryside, in order to create a new [[Communist]] society; 2–3 million displaced. * November 1979 – As a result of the [[1979 Mississauga train derailment]], the city of [[Mississauga]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]] was evacuated following a [[chlorine]] leak after a freight train derailed. 218,000 were displaced. * April 1986 – The [[Chernobyl disaster]] involved an evacuation of an estimated 335,000 people following a [[nuclear meltdown]] at the [[Chernobyl]] [[nuclear power]] plant in [[Ukraine]] (then part of the [[Soviet Union]]).<ref>{{cite web|title=Geographical location and extent of radioactive contamination |work=Chernobyl.info |publisher=[[Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation]] |url=http://www.chernobyl.info/index.php?navID=2 |accessdate=2007-10-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070630071332/http://www.chernobyl.info/index.php?navID=2 |archivedate=2007-06-30 |df= }}</ref> * 13 August to 11 October 1990 – During the [[1990 airlift of Indians from Kuwait]] [[Air India#Awards and recognitions|Air India]] entered the [[Guinness Book of World Records]] for the most people evacuated by a civil airliner. Over 170,000 people were evacuated from [[Amman]] to [[Mumbai]]– a distance of 4,117 km- via 488 flights operated by Indian Airlines. The operation was carried out during the [[Persian Gulf War]] to evacuate Indian [[expatriate]]s from [[Kuwait]] and [[Iraq]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisismyindia.com/air-line/airindia.html |title=Air India, History of Air India, Air India Flight Services, Air India International, Passenger Operations, Awards in Air India |publisher=Thisismyindia.com |access-date=10 June 2010}}</ref> * 24–25 May 1991 – [[Operation Solomon]], covert [[Israel]]i military operation to take 14,325 [[Beta Israel|Ethiopian Jews]] to [[Israel]]. * June 1991 – [[Operation Fiery Vigil]] was the evacuation of roughly 20,000 non-essential military and [[United States Department of Defense]] civilian personnel and their dependents from [[Clark Air Base]] and [[U.S. Naval Base Subic Bay]] back to [[Contiguous United States|CONUS]] during the [[Plinian eruption|eruption]] of [[Mount Pinatubo]] in the [[Philippines]]. * February 1995 – At least 200,000 people are evacuated in the [[Netherlands]] due to flooding.<ref>{{cite news|last=Cowell|first=Alan|title=Dutch Rivers Are Receding, But Danger to Dikes Persists|publisher=''The New York Times''|date=February 3, 1995|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=990CE4D6133CF930A35751C0A963958260|accessdate=2008-06-02 }}</ref> * April 5, 1995 – Nearly 10.000 inhabitants of [[Pergamino, Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]] were evacuated for several days because of [[flood]]ing <ref>{{cite web|title=CAPITULO IV. ESTUDIO DE CASO: PERGAMINO| url= http://www.cambioglobal.org/enso/informes/anho4/Argentina/Cap%204%20ESTUDIO%20DE%20CASO%20-%20PERGAMINO.pdf |publisher= CENTRO estudios sociales y ambientales. INFORME FINAL IAI 2004 ENSO ARGENTINA |date= 2004 |language =es}}</ref> * April 1997 – Nearly 50,000 residents of Grand Forks, North Dakota were evacuated due to flooding from the Red River of the North, which overtopped levees.<ref>Shelby, A. Red River Rising: The Anatomy of a Flood and the Survival of an American City. St. Paul, MN: Minnesota Historical Society Press/Borealis Books, 2003.</ref> *July–August 1998 – Nearly 14 million people were evacuated because of massive [[flood]]ing and [[landslide]]s in north and central [[China]], and 5.6 million houses were destroyed. An additional 300,000 people were evacuated on August 7 in anticipation of a possible breach of [[Levee|dikes]] along the [[Yangtze River]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Officials stage mass evacuations in China's deadly floods|agency=Associated Press|date=August 7, 1998|url= http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/asiapcf/9808/07/china.floods.01/index.html|accessdate=2007-10-25|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080329065755/http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/asiapcf/9808/07/china.floods.01/index.html|archivedate=2008-03-29}}</ref> *1999 – The [[Kosovo War]] led to 800,000 refugees, not all of them urban residents, leaving [[Kosovo]] and being accommodated for up to three months in other parts of [[Europe]]. *September 1999 – The size of [[Hurricane Floyd]], its intensity, and its track prompted public officials to launch the largest evacuation in U.S. history, with an estimated 3 million people fleeing the storm.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fema.gov/news-release/2000/09/14/hurricane-floyd-night-remember-day-evacuation-frustration-forget|title=Hurricane Floyd – A Night To Remember, A Day Of Evacuation Frustration To Forget|last=|first=|date=September 9, 2000|website=|publisher=[[Federal Emergency Management Agency]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2018-11-15}}</ref>
==21st century== [[Image:SDFIRE2007 058brightsharp.jpg|thumb|Evacuees at evacuation site [[Mira Mesa High School]]]]
* April 2001 – 77,000 inhabitants (around 2/3 of the population) of [[Vicenza]], [[Italy]]) were evacuated for several hours so that an [[UXO|unexploded bomb]], originally dropped in World War II, could be safely disarmed.<ref>{{cite news|title=Thousands Evacuated From Italian City to Detonate WWII Bomb|publisher=''People's Daily''|date=April 30, 2001|url=http://english.people.com.cn/english/200104/30/eng20010430_69000.html|accessdate=2007-10-25 }}</ref> * [[September 11 attacks|September 11, 2001]] – Evacuations from [[skyscraper|high-rise buildings]] across the United States. This included 3200+ survivors of the [[Collapse of the World Trade Center|World Trade Center disaster]] and inhabitants of downtown [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]]. Numerous other evacuations of high-rises in [[Chicago]], Illinois included the [[Sears Tower]] and the Thompson Building. The evacuation of New York included the largest sea evacuation in recorded history, with over 500,000 being evacuated in 9 hours by hundreds of boats.<ref name="youtube" /> * January 2002 – 300,000 residents of the city of [[Goma]], [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]] were evacuated in three days due to the eruption of the [[Mount Nyiragongo]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Volcano Risk Reduction: A Case Study from Goma (DRC)|publisher=United Nations Development Programme|date=December 2004|url=http://www.undp.org/cpr/disred/documents/publications/casestudy/goma.pdf|accessdate=2007-10-25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071026124011/http://www.undp.org/cpr/disred/documents/publications/casestudy/goma.pdf|archive-date=2007-10-26|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> *August 2002 – The [[2002 European floods]] led to the evacuation of 50,000 residents of [[Prague]], [[Czech Republic]], on 13 August, with a total of 200,000 Czechs during the second week of August.<ref>{{cite news|title=Prague battles flood waters|publisher=BBC News|date=August 14, 2002|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/2192288.stm|accessdate=2007-10-25 }}</ref> Elsewhere in Europe, more than 120,000 people were evacuated in the [[Germany|German]] city of [[Dresden]], 36,000 in the German state of [[Saxony-Anhalt]], and 1,500 in [[Hungary]].<ref>{{cite web|title=EADRCC Situation Report No. 2 on the Flood/CZECH Republic|publisher=Euro-Atlantic Disaster Response Coordination Centre|url=http://www.nato.int/eadrcc/floods_czech_republic/report_2002_111.pdf|accessdate=2007-10-25 }}</ref> *September 2004 – Evacuation orders were issued for over 2.8 million residents in advance of [[Hurricane Frances]], potentially the largest in Florida's history.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2004/WEATHER/09/05/hurricane.frances/index.html|title=Downgraded Frances blows across Florida|last=|first=|date=2004-09-05|website=CNN.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-15}}</ref> FEMA later granted assistance to 229,500 applicants largely associated with relocation expenses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fema.gov/news-release/2014/08/29/ten-years-later-remembering-hurricane-frances|title=Ten Years Later: Remembering Hurricane Frances|last=|first=|date=2014-08-29|website=fema.gov|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-15}}</ref> *July 2005 – 20,000 people were evacuated from the city of [[Birmingham]] in the [[United Kingdom]] after a security alert due to a [[bomb scare]].<ref>{{cite news|title=British police order evac of central Birmingham district|publisher=USA Today|date=July 10, 2005|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2005-07-09-birmingham-evac_x.htm|accessdate=2008-06-01 }}</ref> *August 2005 – [[Hurricane Katrina]] led to a mass evacuation of the city of [[New Orleans, Louisiana]], with approximately 80% of the city's population of 484,000 evacuating before the storm struck. *September 22, 2005 – At least 2.5 million evacuated coastal [[Texas]] and [[Louisiana]] due to the approach of [[Hurricane Rita]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hro.house.state.tx.us/interim/int79-2.pdf|title=Evacuation Planning in Texas: Before and After Rita|last=|first=|date=2006-02-14|website=|publisher=Texas House of Representatives. Government of Texas.|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-15}}</ref> This is the second largest evacuation in U.S. history, and the third-largest peacetime evacuation in modern times. *October 2007 – More than 1.4 million people were evacuated in the Chinese provinces of [[Zhejiang]] and [[Fujian]] in anticipation of [[Typhoon Krosa (Ineng)|Typhoon Krosa]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Yanping|first=Li|title=China Evacuates 1.4 Million People as Typhoon Krosa Hits Coast|publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.]]|date=October 24, 2007|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601080&sid=ac5j8tBcaZ9w&refer=asia|accessdate=2007-10-25 }}</ref> *October 2007 – [[California wildfires of October 2007|California wildfires]] forced more than 900,000 people in [[Southern California]] to evacuate, making it the largest evacuation in [[California]]'s history<ref>{{cite news|last=Brennan|first=Peter J.|author2=Demian McLean |title=California Fires Rout Almost 1 Million People, Kill 5|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|date=October 24, 2007|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601103&sid=a96ks3dv.3Fo&refer=us|accessdate=2007-10-25 }}</ref> and the largest evacuation for fire in United States history.<ref>http://sosdfireblog.blogspot.com/2007/11/map-shows-massive-evacuation-area.html</ref> *May 2008 – [[2008 Sichuan earthquake]]: Approximately 200,000 people are evacuated in [[Beichuan Qiang Autonomous County|Beichuan County, China]] because of flooding fears after a [[Landslide dam|landslide created dam]] became unstable.<ref>{{cite news|title=China plans mass exodus from quake zone|publisher=CNN|date=May 29, 2008|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/asiapcf/05/30/china.earthquake/|accessdate=2008-06-01 }}</ref> *August 2008 – At least 1.9 million people were evacuated from coastal [[Louisiana]], including New Orleans, for [[Hurricane Gustav]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nola.com/hurricane/index.ssf/2008/08/11_million_people_evacuate_sou.html|title=1.9 million people evacuate south Louisiana|last=Anderson|first=Ed|date=2008-08-31|publisher=The Times-Picayune|accessdate=2008-09-01}}</ref> In western [[Cuba]], at least 300,000 people were evacuated.<ref>{{cite web|author=Will Weissert|publisher=BlueRidgeNow|date=2008-08-30|accessdate=2008-09-01|title=Gustav now Category 4, winds of 145 mph|url=http://www.blueridgenow.com/article/20080830/news/808300290}}</ref> *March 2011 – Following the [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]], between 170,000 and 200,000 people are evacuated within a 50-mile radius of the [[Fukushima I Nuclear Power Plant]] in fear of large casualties due to [[radiation poisoning]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Radiation spike forces evacuations at Fukushima nuclear power station|publisher=guardian.co.uk home |date=March 16, 2011|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/mar/16/fukushima-workers-evacuate-radiation-spikes/|accessdate=2011-03-19|location=London|first=Justin|last=McCurry}}</ref> *August 2011 – A mass evacuation stretching from [[North Carolina]] to [[New York (state)|New York]] was ordered because of [[Hurricane Irene (2011)|Hurricane Irene]] and its size.<ref>{{cite news|work=New York Times|date=August 27, 2011|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/28/us/28hurricane-irene.html|first1=Kim|last1=Severson|first2=Dan|last2=Barry|first3=Campbell|last3=Robertson|title=Damage and Flooding Scar Atlantic Seaboard}}</ref> *June 2013 – Nearly 1,000,000 people evacuated in 12 days from [[Uttarakhand]], [[India]] due to a [[flash flood]] and landslide. This operation was completed by the [[Indian Air Force]], [[ITBP]], [[National Disaster Response Force|NDRF]], and local authorities. [[Helicopter]]s were widely used because road networks were severely damaged. *October 2013 – Nearly 975,000 people (world Bank report says close to 100,000 people) were evacuated in 36 hours from the coastal areas of [[Odisha]] (more than 850,000) and [[Andhra Pradesh]] (nearly 90,000) in the face of [[Cyclone Phailin]]. This operation was completed by the [[Indian Air Force]], [[ITBP]], [[Odisha Disaster Response Force|ODRF]], and local authorities. *December 2014 – Nearly 1,000,000 people were evacuated in the eastern [[Philippines]] before [[typhoon]] [[Typhoon Hagupit (2014)|Hagupit]].<ref>https://news.yahoo.com/typhoon-hagupit-triggers-massive-evacuation-philippines-021318742.html</ref> *April 2015 – [[Operation Maitri]] was carried out by India to evacuate stranded Indian citizens and foreigners from [[Nepal]] and humanitarian relief during the Nepal earthquake of magnitude 8.8. *April 2015 – [[Operation Raahat (India)]] was carried out by India to evacuate stranded Indian citizens from [[Yemen]]. A total of 4640 Indian citizens and 960 foreign nationals were rescued.<ref>{{cite web | title=India evacuates 4,640 nationals, 960 others from Yemen | website=www.oneindia.com | date=2015-04-10 | url=http://www.oneindia.com/india/india-evacuates-4640-nationals-960-others-from-yemen-1711703.html | access-date=2015-04-11}}</ref> *May 2016 – Approximately 88,000 people were evacuated from [[Fort McMurray]] (Canada) due to a [[2016 Fort McMurray Wildfire|wildfire]] that grew out of control quickly. This was the largest evacuation in the Province of Alberta's history. Evacuees went north to [[Oil Sands]] camps, and communities to the south.<ref>{{cite news | title=Wildfire rages in Fort McMurray as evacuees settle in Edmonton | website=www.CBC.ca | date=2016-05-04 | url=http://www.cbc.ca/beta/news/canada/edmonton/wildfire-rages-in-fort-mcmurray-as-evacuees-settle-in-edmonton | access-date=2015-05-04}}</ref> *October 2016 – More than 2.5 million people were told to evacuate in [[Florida]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] and [[South Carolina]] due to the approach of [[Hurricane Matthew]], becoming the tenth most destructive in U.S. history.<ref>{{cite web | title=Hurricane Matthew batters Florida’s northeast coast; four deaths linked to storm|date=2016-08-07| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2016/10/07/hurricane-matthew-rumbles-along-floridas-coast-as-governor-warns-this-is-not-over/| access-date=2016-08-10}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.palmbeachdailynews.com/weather/hurricanes/experts-why-didn-people-evacuate-for-hurricane-matthew/t2LElTY1htABbNLu7kcMVM/?start=2|title=Why Didn't People Evacuate for Hurricane Matthew?|last=|first=|date=2017-06-01|website=Palm Beach Daily News|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-15}}</ref> *February 2017 – Evacuation of 188,000 civilians from the city of Oroville, California and other towns near the [[Oroville Dam]] due to impending failure of auxiliary spillway systems.<ref>http://www.cnn.com/2017/02/13/us/california-oroville-dam-spillway-failure/index.html</ref> *July to September 2017 - Evacuation of [[Cariboo Regional District]], British Columbia, Canada, resulted in 35,616 people under evacuation order or alert over 77 days due to a record-setting wildfire season, with 996,141 hectares burnt in 232 fires, and 60 homes and 167 other structures destroyed over 48,099 km<sup>2</sup>. No deaths were recorded.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cariboord.bc.ca/services/emergency-and-protective-services/emergency-operations-centre-eoc|title=Emergency Operations Centre (EOC) {{!}} Cariboo Regional District|website=Cariboo Regional District|language=en|access-date=2017-11-07}}</ref> *September 2017 ─ One week after [[Hurricane Harvey]] rampaged coastal Texas and Louisana, 7 million people (in [[Florida]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], and [[South Carolina]]) were told to evacuate due to [[Hurricane Irma]]. Low estimates of the actual number of evacuees is 700,000 people.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/nation/2017/09/09/magnitude-irma-drives-massive-evacuation-from-florida/cdbZjGJrvgIF0Todpws4VJ/story.html}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Mass evacuation}} [[Category:Accidents]] [[Category:Lists of disasters]] [[Category:Evacuations|Evacuations]]

revision.comment: Reverted 3 edits by [[Special:Contributions/Lhill24|Lhill24]] ([[User talk:Lhill24|talk]]) to last revision by 138.51.127.50. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
The following is a list of historically famous prison escapes, and of multiple prison escapes:
==Famous historical escapes== [[File:Famous adventures and prison escapes of the civil war (1893) (14573020789).jpg|{{largethumb}}|On November 27, 1863, [[John Hunt Morgan]] and six of his officers, most notably [[Thomas Hines]], escaped from their cells in the [[Ohio Penitentiary]] by digging a tunnel from Hines' cell into the inner yard and then ascending a wall with a rope made from bunk coverlets and a bent poker iron.]]
There have been many infamous escapes throughout history:
===13th century=== * In 1244, whilst imprisoned in the [[Tower of London]], [[Gruffydd ap Llywelyn Fawr]] crafted a make-shift rope made of bed sheets and cloths, lowered it, and climbed down. However, because he was heavy, the rope broke and as a consequence, he fell to his death.<ref>https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=8QY7AAAAQBAJ&pg=PT135&dq=gruffydd+ap+llywelyn+fawr+death+rope&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi2i-Gvif7XAhVE-qQKHbfaD2sQ6AEINzAC#v=onepage&q=gruffydd%20ap%20llywelyn%20fawr%20death%20rope&f=false</ref>
===17th century=== * In 1621 Dutch author [[Hugo Grotius]] escaped from [[Loevestein|Loevestein Castle]] where he was held captive by hiding himself inside a book chest. He was then smuggled outside.
===18th century===
* Englishman [[Jack Sheppard]] took to theft and burglary in 1723, and was arrested and imprisoned five times in 1724 but escaped four times, making him a notorious public figure and wildly popular with the poorer classes. * The Italian author and adventurer [[Giacomo Casanova]] escaped from prison in 1757.
===19th century=== *In the [[Libby Prison Escape]], during the [[American Civil War]], over 109 [[Union (American Civil War)|Union]] [[POWs]] broke out of a building at [[Libby Prison]] in [[Richmond, Virginia]] on the night between February 9 and February 10, 1864. All but 50 (two were drowned in the nearby [[James River (Virginia)|James River]]) successfully reached back to Union lines. *The notorious outlaw [[Billy The Kid]] managed to escape from prison in 1881, but was captured and shot by [[Pat Garrett]] only a few months later.
===1900–1950=== * In 1901, [[Lum You]] was convicted of murder and sentenced to death by a [[Pacific County, Washington]] court. He enjoyed great public sympathy, including from county officials, who supposedly allowed him to escape by leaving his cell door unlocked at night. He eventually seized the opportunity, but within a few days he either gave himself up or was recaptured.<ref name="stevens">{{cite news|first=Sydney |last=Stevens |title=Behind Bars in Old Pacific County, 1902: The Hanging of Lum You |newspaper=Chinook Observer |date=June 7, 2011 |url=http://www.chinookobserver.com/news/history/the-hanging-of-lum-you/article_303b3b2a-912f-11e0-a1e7-001cc4c002e0.html |accessdate=August 18, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130503121544/http://www.chinookobserver.com/news/history/the-hanging-of-lum-you/article_303b3b2a-912f-11e0-a1e7-001cc4c002e0.html |archivedate=May 3, 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref name="espy">{{cite book | first=Willard R. | last=Espy | authorlink=Willard R. Espy | title=Oysterville: Roads to Grandpa's Village |year=1976 |publisher=University of Washington Press |isbn=0-517-52196-2 |pages=142–143}}</ref> * German Naval Air Service Kapitänleutnant [[Gunther Plüschow]] escaped from the [[Donington Hall]] [[prisoner of war camp]] in 1915. * [[Frederick Mors]], an Austrian-born American serial killer, was declared insane and placed into the Matteawan Institution for the Insane in the United States in 1915. He escaped in 1916 and was never seen again. *Leonard T. Fristoe was imprisoned for double murder in 1920 of a police Constable and a deputy Sherriff in Nevada.<ref>[https://www.odmp.org/officer/17466-constable-arthur-j-st-clair ODMP memorial]</ref> He escaped from Nevada State Prison in 1923. He lived for nearly 46 years under the allias of Claude R. Willis, before being turned in by his own son.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/records-11000/longest-prison-escape/ |title=Longest prison escape |publisher=Guinnessworldrecords.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-15}}</ref> After serving several years in prison he died of natural causes . * [[John Dillinger]] served time at the Indiana State Penitentiary at Michigan City, until 1933, when he was paroled. Within four months, he was back in jail in [[Lima, Ohio]], but his gang sprang him, killing the jailer, Sheriff Jessie Sarber. Most of the gang was captured again by the end of the year in [[Tucson, Arizona]], due to a fire at the Historic Hotel Congress. Dillinger alone was sent to the Lake County jail in [[Crown Point, Indiana]]. He was to face trial for the suspected killing of police officer William O'Malley during a bank shootout in [[East Chicago, Indiana]], some time after his escape from jail. During this time on trial, a famous photograph was taken of Dillinger putting his arm on prosecutor Robert Estill's shoulder when suggested to him by reporters. * On March 3, 1934, Dillinger escaped from the "escape-proof" (as it was dubbed by local authorities at the time) Crown Point, Indiana county jail, which was guarded by many police officers and national guardsmen. Newspapers reported that Dillinger had escaped using a fake gun made from wood, blackened and shined with shoe polish. * French prisoner [[René Belbenoît]] escaped from the penal colony of French Guiana on March 2, 1935 when he and five others took to the sea with a boat they had bought. After a series of daring adventures, during which all of the other escapees were captured, he reached United States in 1937. In 1938 his account, ''Dry Guillotine'', was published. Belbenoît had written it in French and it was translated in English by Preston Rambo. It went through 14 printings in less than a year. * Japanese murderer [[Yoshie Shiratori]] broke out of prison four times between the 1930s and 1940s. A novel and TV-drama ''Hagoku'' was based on his true story. * [[Fort San Cristóbal (Spain)|Fort San Cristóbal]] is located on the top of the mountain San Cristóbal, which is very close (4 km) to [[Pamplona]], [[Spain]]. Built inside the mountain and obsolete since its opening in 1919, due to its weakness against aviation, it served as a prison. On May 22, 1938, during the [[Spanish Civil War]], around 30 prisoners organised a mutiny for a massive prison break. 792 prisoners fled but only three succeeded in getting to the [[France|French]] border; 585 were arrested, 211 died and 14 of the arrested who were considered the leaders were sentenced to death. Most fugitives were intercepted during the following days. In 1988, a sculpture was erected to honour the memory of the Republican people dead there. The fort ceased to be a prison in 1945. * [[Colditz Castle]] was used as an "escape-proof" prisoner-of-war camp during [[World War II]], but over the course of 300 escape attempts, 130 prisoners escaped.{{Citation needed|date=December 2007}} Thirty escapees eventually managed to reach friendly territory. The men had tunneled, disguised themselves as guards, workmen or women, sneaked away through sewer drains, and even planned to use a glider to get over the wall. * [[André Devigny]], a French resistance fighter during World War II, escaped [[Fort Montluc|Montluc Military Prison]] in Lyons with his cellmate in April 1943. * French author [[Henri Charrière]] tried to escape in vain several times, but eventually was successful in 1943. His story, ''[[Papillon (book)|Papillon]]'', was published and filmed [[Papillon (1973 film)|under the same name]]. * In [[Stalag Luft III|the Great Escape]], 76 Allied POWs (primarily Commonwealth airmen) escaped from [[Stalag Luft III]] during World War II. 73 of the escapees were captured and fifty of them were executed by the [[Gestapo]], while only three succeeded in reaching neutral territories. *In the [[Cowra breakout]], at least 545 out of approximately 1000 Japanese POWs escaped from Number 12 POW Compound at Cowra on the night of 4 August 1944. Out of the roughly 500 escapees, 231 died and 108 were wounded. 31 killed themselves and 12 were burnt to death in huts set on fire by the Japanese. Sixteen of the wounded showed signs of attempted suicide.<ref name="memorial">{{cite book|last=Long|first=Gavin|year=1963|chapter-url=https://www.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070308--1-.pdf|url=https://www.awm.gov.au/collection/RCDIG1070206/|title=The Final Campaigns|chapter=Appendix 5 – The Prison Break at Cowra, August 1944|series=Australia in the War of 1939–1945. Series 1 – Army|volume=Volume 7|location=Canberra|publisher=Australian War Memorial|oclc=1297619|pp=623–624}}</ref> *In the [[Great Papago Escape]], over 25 German POWs escaped by tunneling out of [[Camp Papago Park|Camp Papago Park POW facility]], near [[Phoenix, Arizona]], on the night of December 23, 1944. They then fled into the surrounding desert but because the rivers in Arizona were mostly dry and had not been navigable for decades, most of them were recaptured without bloodshed over the next few weeks. *In the [[Acre Prison break]], 28 members of the Jewish underground groups [[Irgun]] and [[Lehi (group)|Lehi]] escaped from [[Acre Prison]] in [[Acre, Israel|Acre]], [[Mandatory Palestine]] (now [[Israel]]) on May 4, 1947.
===1950–1975=== *In 1959, [[Frank Freshwaters]] escaped from an Ohio prison while serving a sentence of involuntary manslaughter from a 1957 car accident. After 56 years he was arrested in Florida.<ref>[http://www.ibtimes.com/shawshank-redemption-real-frank-freshwater-captured-after-56-years-run-fugitive-1910767 IB Tribune]</ref> *In the [[June 1962 Alcatraz escape|Alcatraz escape on June 11, 1962]], American criminals brothers [[June 1962 Alcatraz escape#John and Clarence Anglin|John and Clarence Anglin]], and [[Frank Morris (prisoner)|Frank Morris]] escaped [[Alcatraz Federal Penitentiary]] on [[Alcatraz Island]] using an inflatable raft, never to be seen again. It was never determined by the [[FBI]] whether they succeeded in their escape or died in the attempt. *In 1973, three [[Provisional Irish Republican Army]] prisoners escaped in the [[1973 Mountjoy Prison helicopter escape|Mountjoy Prison helicopter escape]], when a hijacked helicopter landed in the exercise yard at [[Mountjoy Prison]], [[Dublin]], [[Republic of Ireland]]. *In 1975, 28-year-old American convicted [[drug smuggler]] [[Billy Hayes (writer)|Billy Hayes]] escaped from a prison in [[İmralı]], [[Turkey]], using a rowboat. He made his way to [[Istanbul]], then to Greece, where he was eventually deported to the U.S. Hayes wrote a book on his experiences, ''[[Midnight Express (book)|Midnight Express]]'', which was later adapted into the 1978 film ''[[Midnight Express (film)|of the same name]]'' starring [[Brad Davis (actor)|Brad Davis]] as Hayes.
===1975–1999=== *On 5 April 1976, in the [[Segovia prison break]], twenty nine prisoners escape from prison, in Spain's largest prison break since the country's [[Spanish civil war|civil war]]. The majority belong to the [[Basque nationalism|Basque]] [[separatism|separatist]] group [[ETA (separatist group)|ETA]]. The majority of prisoners are recaptured in shoot outs with the authorities in the next few days, during which one escapee is killed, though four manage to escape to France. *In 1977, the convicted murderer of [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]], [[James Earl Ray]], escaped from Brushy Mountain State Prison in Tennessee, along with six others. Ray was recaptured after two days. He had been running and hiding in the mountainous forest surrounding the prison. *In 1977, convicted murderer James Robert Jones escaped from prison in Kansas, and lived in Florida for 37 years under the alias of Bruce Walter Keith. He was arrested in March 2014. It is assumed that he used someone else's identity.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=11222409 |title=Murderer caught after 37 years on run - World - NZ Herald News |publisher=Nzherald.co.nz |date=2014-03-19 |accessdate=2014-05-15}}</ref> *In 1979, [[Assata Shakur]] successfully escaped prison in Union, New Jersey when three members of the Black Liberation Army took prison guards as hostages, freed Assata and fled in a prison van. No one was injured during the prison break, including the guards-turned-hostages who were left in the parking lot. In 1984, Shakur escaped to Cuba where she gained political asylum. Shakur was moved to the FBI's Most Wanted Terrorists List on May 2, 2013. * On 2 March 1982 in [[Peru]], [[Shining Path|PCP]] guerilla fighters [[Assault of Ayacucho prison|assaulted the Ayacucho prison]], resulting in the release of 255 inmates. * In the [[1983 Batticaloa Jailbreak]] on 23 September 1983, 41 [[Tamil people|Tamil]] political prisoners and 151 criminal prisoners escaped in eastern [[Sri Lanka]]. * In the [[Maze Prison escape]] on 25 September 1983, 38 [[Provisional Irish Republican Army]] members escaped from [[HMP Maze]] in [[Northern Ireland]], the biggest prison escape in Irish or British history. * In 1984, six death row inmates escaped [[Mecklenburg Correctional Center]], making it the largest mass death row escape in American history. All were recaptured within 18 days, and all six men would eventually be executed. The final execution took place in 1996. * On 7 March 1993, [[Peter Gibb]] and Archie Butterley escaped from the [[HM Melbourne Assessment Prison|Melbourne Remand Centre]] in Australia, with the help of prison guard Heather Parker who was having a relationship with Gibb. Police found Butterley shot dead six days later, and re-captured Gibb. * [[Trikala]], [[Greece]], on May 23, 1995, Albanian inmates staged a daring escape from an old Turkish administration building-turned-prison, using weight dumbbells to break the locks of the gates and bed springs as a ladder to scale the wall. 29 prisoners escaped, and about half of them absconded to [[Albania]] and were never recaptured. Only Albanian inmates escaped, having kept escape plans secret from the prison's international population. * In the [[1995 Vellore Fort Jailbreak]] on 15 August 1995, 43 [[Tamil Tigers|Tamil Tiger]] inmates escaped from [[Vellore Fort]] prison in India. * In 1998, the Belgian child molester [[Marc Dutroux]] notoriously managed to escape for a few hours. He was caught the same afternoon, but the incident forced two politicians to resign and deepened the loss of faith in the Belgian judicial system.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/88889.stm|title=BBC News - EUROPE - Dutroux re-enacts escape|publisher=}}</ref> * Martin Gurule escaped from the Texas Death Row at [[Ellis Unit]] in 1998. He was found dead a few days later.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=PIVIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=1m8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6786%2C1664984 | title=Inmate found dead near breakout site | work=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette | date=Dec 4, 1998 | accessdate=14 May 2015 | author=Graczyk, Michael | pages=A13}}</ref> * In 1999, [[Leslie Dale Martin]] and three other inmates on [[Louisiana]]'s [[death row]] escaped from their cells at the [[Louisiana State Penitentiary]]. They were caught within hours, before they even managed to escape prison grounds. The four men had managed the escape with the use of [[hacksaws]] that had been smuggled in for them by a bribed corrections officer. Other officers were inattentive to the inmates' two to three week effort at cutting their cell doors and window. After the escape, two corrections officers were fired and two others were demoted. Two corrections officers later overheard Martin plotting another escape, which included taking hostages and commandeering a vehicle to ram the prison's front gates. Martin was immediately moved to the holding cell outside the [[death chamber]], a month before his [[execution]] in 2002.
===2000–present===
* The [[Texas Seven|Texas 7]] escaped from [[John B. Connally Unit]] on December 13, 2000. Six of them were captured after over a month and a half on the run; the seventh killed himself before being captured. * In January 2001, three inmates escaped from [[Chicago State Penitentiary]]'s H-Unit (Hi-Max). One of them was injured during the escape, and while trying to get back into the prison he got caught in the razor between the fences. The other two offenders (one serving a life sentence for murder, the other for rape and kidnapping) were at large for several days before being apprehended in a small town approximately {{convert|40|mi|km}} from the prison. * In New York, two convicted murderers escaped from Elmira State Penitentiary in July 2003; both were recaptured in two days. * [[Colton Harris-Moore]] fled a three-year sentence by walking out of a [[halfway house]] in April 2008. On 11 July 2010, he was captured at [[Harbour Island, Bahamas]] and sent back to [[Seattle]] * The [[Sarposa Prison attack]] was a raid on the [[Kandahar detention facility]] in [[Kandahar]], [[Afghanistan]] by [[Taliban]] insurgents on June 13, 2008. One of the largest attacks by Afghan insurgents, the raid freed 400-1000 prisoners. * On August 4, 2008, [[Sarah Jo Pender]] escaped from [[Rockville Correctional Facility]] with the help of prison guard Scott Spitler, who was expecting a $15,000 payment.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://caselaw.findlaw.com/in-court-of-appeals/1219359.html|title=FindLaw's Court of Appeals of Indiana case and opinions.|publisher=}}</ref> She remained on the run for four months. * Eight inmates charged with violent crimes [[Clovis, New Mexico jail break|escaped from the Curry County Adult Detention Center]] in [[Clovis, New Mexico|Clovis]], [[New Mexico]] on August 24, 2008. The men escaped by climbing prison pipes in a narrow space inside a wall, then using homemade instruments to cut a hole in the roof. The jailbreak was featured on a September 6 episode of ''[[America's Most Wanted]]''. As of October 2010, convicted murderer Edward Salas was the only inmate still at large. Salas was taken into custody by the U.S. Marshals Service on Thursday, October 4, 2012 in Chihuahua City, Mexico, and was extradited back to New Mexico.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newschannel10.com/story/19747509/fbis-most-wanted-captured |title=Convicted killer Edward Salas captured in Mexico|publisher=[[KFDA-TV]] |accessdate= 2012-10-15}}</ref> * Lance Battreal, Charles Smith, and Mark Booher escaped from a [[Michigan City, Indiana]] prison on July 12, 2009 through underground tunnels under the prison yard.<ref>[http://www.wishtv.com/dpp/news/crime/3_inmates_escape_Michigan_City_prison_20090712 "3 inmates escape Michigan City prison"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120303075204/http://www.wishtv.com/dpp/news/crime/3_inmates_escape_Michigan_City_prison_20090712 |date=2012-03-03 }} ''[[WISH-TV]]'' Retrieved on 2009-07-23</ref> Smith was captured on July 20, 2009 near Chicago Mayor [[Richard M. Daley]]'s vacation home in [[Grand Beach, Michigan|Grand Beach]], [[Michigan]].<ref>[http://www.thestarpress.com/article/20090714/NEWS01/907140306 "One Henry County killer caught near Chicago mayors home"]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ''[[The Star Press]]'' Retrieved on 2009-07-23</ref> Battreal was captured on July 21, 2009 at his mother's house in [[Rockport, Indiana]].<ref>[http://www.wivb.com/dpp/news/nation/midwest/nat_ap_rockport_2nd_of_3_indiana_prison_escapees_captured_20090721716_2663789 "2nd of 3 Ind. prison escapees captured"] ''[[WIVB]]'' Retrieved on 2009-07-23</ref> Booher was captured on July 23, 2009 in a hotel in [[Indianapolis]], [[Indiana]].<ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2009/CRIME/07/23/indiana.prison.escape/ "Last of three prison escapees captured in Indiana"] ''[[CNN]]''</ref> *Three inmates at an [[Arizona State Prison - Kingman|Arizona State Prison]] for-profit [[Management and Training Corporation]]-operated facility escaped on July 30, 2010. Daniel Renwick and Tracy Province were murderers and John McCluskey had been convicted of attempted murders. Renwick was captured in a shootout in Rifle, Colorado on August 1, 2010. Though he still had 32 years on his sentence in Arizona, he was sentenced to 60 years to be served in Colorado. Province, already a lifer, was captured on August 9, 2010 in Meeteese, Wyoming.<ref>{{cite web|title=First Inmate Sentenced in Arizona Prison Escape|url=http://www.lvrj.com/news/first-inmate-charged-in-arizona-prison-escape-114812684.html|accessdate=31 July 2011}}</ref> After being sentenced to 38 1/3 years in Arizona, he was quickly extradited to face murder charges in New Mexico. McCluskey, who had been doing consecutive 15-year sentences, was captured with Casslyn Welch, his cousin/accomplice, in eastern Arizona on August 19 in the Apache-Sitgreaves National Forest. He was sentenced to 43 years in an Arizona prison on escape, kidnap, hijacking and robbery charges.<ref>{{cite web|title=Arizona inmate gets 43 years for his escape|url=http://www.lvrj.com/news/arizona-inmate-gets-43-years-in-prison-after-escape-124114574.html|accessdate=19 June 2011}}</ref> Like Province, Welch and McCluskey were soon extradited for the alleged robbery, hijack and murder of two vacationers in New Mexico. [[Kenneth John Gonzales]], the U.S. Attorney in New Mexico, filed death penalty charges against all three. McCluskey was convicted after a three-month trial in Albuquerque on October 7, 2013, after Province and Welch testified against him, a conditions of their plea bargains. The death penalty phase of the proceedings began on October 21,<ref>[https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/10/07/arizona-inmate-murder/2939801 "Inmate convicted of killing retired couple while on the lam"], [[U.S.A. Today]], 7 October 2013. Retrieved 16 October 2013</ref> but the jury delivered a sentence of life imprisonment for McCluskey, and Province received the same. Welch was sentenced to 40 years.<ref>[http://www.abqjournal.com/409968/news/40-years-for-womans-role-in-murders.html "40 Years for Woman's Role in Murders"], [[Albuquerque Journal]], Scott Sandlin. June 2, 2014. Retrieved 25 February 2016.</ref> * On July 27, 2013, 1,000 inmates escaped from the Queyfiya prison near [[Benghazi]], [[Libya]]. The escape occurred after a wave of political assassinations and attacks on political offices around the country. Local residents of Benghazi forced the inmates out of the prison. * In October 2013, Kevin Patrick Stoeser escaped from the Austin Transitional Center where he was serving the remainder of a 156-month sentence for four counts of child sexual assault and one count of possession of child pornography. He pleaded guilty to these charges in 2003. He was never captured but DNA-confirmed remains of his skull were found near Del Valle, Texas on September 8, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usmarshals.gov/investigations/most_wanted/stoeser/stoeser-111714.htm|title=U.S. Marshals 15 Most Wanted Fugitive’s Skull Found by Family Dog|publisher=}}</ref> *On June 8, 2014, Robert Elbryan, 42, Joe Game, 53, and George Broussard, 63, escaped from a Quebec detention center with help from a helicopter. The three men were arrested a couple weeks later and returned to the same facility.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/06/22/world/americas/canada-helicopter-jailbreak/index.html|title=Escapees in Canadian helicopter jailbreak captured - CNN.com|first=By Michael Pearson|last=CNN|publisher=}}</ref> *On September 11, 2014, TJ Lane, 19, serving three life sentences for [[Chardon High School shooting|indiscriminately killing fellow students at his Ohio high school in 2012]], and Jay Morris, 20, escaped [[Allen Correctional Institution]]. Rodriguez was apprehended about 5 hours later, and Morris was captured about 8 hours later.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/09/11/justice/ohio-school-shooter-escapes/index.html|title=Convicted killer T.J. Lane captured after escape - CNN.com|first=By Ed Payne and Cristy Lenz|last=CNN|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wkyc.com/story/news/local/northeast-ohio/2014/09/11/tj-lane-escape/15485863/|title=CAPTURED - Chardon shooter T.J. Lane in custody|first=|last=TEGNA|publisher=}}</ref> *On June 6, 2015, [[Richard Matt]], 48, and David Sweat, 34, were [[2015 Clinton Correctional Facility escape|discovered missing]] from the [[Clinton Correctional Facility]] in [[Dannemora (village), New York|Dannemora, New York]] during a head count at 5:30am. An "external breach" was found on a street approximately 500 feet south of the prison wall. Both inmates had been convicted of murder. Richard Matt was shot dead on June 26, 2015 near Lake Titus in Upstate New York. Two days later on June 28, 2015, David Sweat was captured just miles from the Canada–US border, shot twice before taken to a local hospital. *On July 11, 2015, Mexican drug lord [[Joaquín Guzmán|Joaquín Guzmán Loera]], also known as 'El Chapo', escaped from Federal Social Readaptation Center No.1, a maximum security prison. His escape involved an elaborate underground tunnel leading from the shower area in his cell stretching 1.5 km to a house construction site. The shower area in his cell was not detectable to the security cameras, creating a blind spot. The tunnel lay 10 meters underground and was equipped with a ladder to climb to the bottom, artificial lights, air ducts and various construction materials. A makeshift motorcycle was found in the tunnel, believed to have been used to excavate the tons of earth removed, transport materials and Guzmán himself. An investigation and manhunt quickly followed. He was recaptured on January 8, 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/CNNMex/status/685527281587097601|title=CNN México on Twitter|work=Twitter|accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref> *On January 22, 2016, three inmates escaped the [[Orange County Sheriff's Department (California)#Jails|Orange County Men's Central Jail]], a maximum security jail in [[Orange County, California]]. The three inmates (Jonathan Tieu, 20; Hossein Nayeri, 37; and Bac Tien Duong, 43) cut through steel bars, made their way through plumbing tunnels, and a used a makeshift rope made out of bed sheets to rappel down the multistory facility.<ref>{{Cite web|title = California jail escape: 3 inmates on the loose - CNN.com|url = http://www.cnn.com/2016/01/24/us/california-escaped-inmates/index.html|website = CNN|access-date = 2016-01-30}}</ref> Bac Tien Duong surrendered to police in Santa Ana CA on January 29. The other two inmates, Hossein Nayeri and Jonathan Tieu, were arrested in San Francisco on January 30. *On November 7, 2016, two inmates escaped HMP Pentonville in North London. The two inmates (Mathew Baker and James Whitlock) used diamond-tipped cutting equipment to break through cell bars before they scaled the perimeter wall. They left mannequins in their beds to fool the prison guards.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-37899401|title=Two Pentonville prisoners escape over perimeter wall|date=2016-11-07|newspaper=BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-11-07}}</ref> Two days later, Baker was found – with dyed hair and a fractured leg – hiding under a bed at his sister’s home. Whitlock was found at an address in Homerton, east London, after six days on the run.

He escaped from Nottingham Prison after sneaking through the locked doors and over a 20-foot prison wall. |- | 1956 | Law Courts in [[London]] | {{flag|GBR}} |After his arrest, he brought a lawsuit against authorities charging the prison commissioners with illegal arrest and used the incident to plan his next escape. He escaped but was captured at an airport five hours later. |- | 1957 | [[Chelmsford Prison]] | {{flag|GBR}} |He escaped from Chelmsford Prison less than a year later. Two years later he was arrested after being stopped in an unregistered car. |- |rowspan=3|Collen Chauke (1970 – 2003) |rowspan=3| 3 | 1993 | Johannesburg Prison | {{flag|RSA}} |He was convicted for car theft and sentenced for four years imprisonment. He escaped from prison after serving only one month of his sentence.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://152.111.1.87/argief/berigte/citypress/2003/11/23/C1/4/02.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-06-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160701171642/http://152.111.1.87/argief/berigte/citypress/2003/11/23/C1/4/02.html |archivedate=2016-07-01 |df= }}</ref> |- | 1997 | Pretoria Prison | {{flag|RSA}} |He was found guilty of robbing R12,6-million from a depot of the SBV security company in Pretoria in October 1997. He manage to escape from Pretoria prison with five others in December 1997. |- | 1998 | Pretoria Prison | {{flag|RSA}} |He escaped from prison and manage to evade the police for a year until he was recaptured in 1999 in [[Nelspruit]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2003-11-21-collen-chauke-dies-in-hospital|title=Collen Chauke dies in hospital|first=Staff|last=Reporter|publisher=}}</ref> |- |rowspan=3|{{sortname|Richard Lee|McNair}} (born 1958) |rowspan=3| 3 | 1988 | [[Minot, North Dakota|Minot]] municipal police station | {{flag|USA}} | He used [[lip balm]] to squeeze out of handcuffs. |- | 1992, October | [[North Dakota State Penitentiary]] | {{flag|USA}} | He escaped by crawling through a ventilation duct. |- | 2006, April 5 | [[United States Penitentiary, Pollock]] | {{flag|USA}} |He mailed himself out of prison in a crate. McNair was captured in October 2007 in Canada and is now held at the [[ADX Florence]] [[supermax]] facility in Colorado.<ref name="LLL">Bayens, Stuart P. [http://www.lastlinkontheleft.com/e1987mcnair.html "Deadmonton - Richard Lee McNair"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140315193038/http://www.lastlinkontheleft.com/e1987mcnair.html |date=2014-03-15 }}. ''Last Link on the Left''. May 15, 2009. Retrieved September 22, 2011.</ref> |- |rowspan=3|{{sortname|Willie|Sutton}} (1901-1980) |rowspan=3| 3 | 1932, December 11 | [[Sing Sing]] | {{flag|USA}} |He was an [[United States of America|American]] named “The Actor” and “Slick Willie”. In June 1931 he was sentenced to 30 years on charges of assault and robbery. He escaped on 11 December 1932, by scaling the prison wall on two 9-foot sections of ladder that were joined together. Sutton was apprehended on 5 February 1934 and was sentenced to serve 25–50 years in Eastern State Penitentiary, for a machine gun robbery of the Corn Exchange Bank. |- | 1945, April 3 | [[Eastern State Penitentiary]] | {{flag|USA}} |He was one of 12 convicts who escaped the institution through a tunnel. He was recaptured the same day by Philadelphia police officers, his fifth escape attempt at this prison. Sentenced to life imprisonment as a fourth time offender, he was transferred to the Philadelphia County Prison. |- | 1947, February 10 | Philadelphia County Prison | {{flag|USA}} |He and other prisoners dressed as prison guards and escaped via ladders across the prison yard to the wall.<ref>[https://www.fbi.gov/about-us/history/famous-cases/willie-sutton ''Willie Sutton''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160427070608/https://www.fbi.gov/about-us/history/famous-cases/willie-sutton |date=2016-04-27 }}, FBI, accessdate 2 January 2014</ref> |- |rowspan=2|{{sortname|Pascal|Payet}} |rowspan=2| 2 | 2001, October 12 | [[Luynes, Bouches-du-Rhône|Luynes]] prison | {{flag|FRA}} | rowspan=2|Payet (born 1963) is a [[France|French]] criminal who gained notoriety for his daring prison escapes using helicopters. He was initially sentenced to a 30-year jail term for a murder committed during the robbery of a security van in 1997. He escaped two times with a helicopter. After his second escape he was captured on September 21, 2007.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/6899274.stm | title = French inmate in second breakout | publisher = BBC | accessdate = July 15, 2007 | date=2007-07-14}}</ref><ref>{{fr icon}} [http://tempsreel.nouvelobs.com/actualites/societe/20070715.OBS6671/pascal_payet_sest_evade_en_helicopterede_la_maison_darr.html ''Pascal Payet s'est évadé en hélicoptère de la maison d'arrêt de Grasse''], [[Nouvelobs interactif|Nouvelobs.com]], 15/07/2007</ref><ref>{{fr icon}} [http://www.lepoint.fr/actualites/2007-09-21/payet-auteur-d-une-evasion-en-helicoptere-arrete-en-espagne/1037/0/201885 ''Payet, auteur d'une évasion en hélicoptère, arrêté en Espagne''], [[Le Point]], 22/09/2007</ref> |- | 2007, July 14 | Prison in [[Grasse]] | {{flag|FRA}} |- |rowspan=2|{{sortname|John|Dillinger}} (1903-1934) |rowspan=2| 2 | 1933, October 13 | [[Allen Correctional Institution|Allen County Jail]] | {{flag|USA}} |He was a notorious bank robber who operated throughout the Midwest during the [[Great Depression]]. He broke out of the Allen County Jail in [[Lima, Ohio]] by having his gang pose as officers and infiltrate the prison. Only a few months later, the gang was re-captured when the hotel they were staying in caught fire. He was incarcerated while waiting to stand trial for the murder of a police officer in a bank robbery. |- | 1934, March 3 | [[Lake County, Indiana|Lake County]] Jail | {{flag|USA}} | Officials boasted that the Lake County Jail in [[Crown Point, Indiana]] was escape-proof and posted extra guards, but he escaped using a fake gun. |- |rowspan=2|{{sortname|Richard|Matt}} (1967-2015) |rowspan=2| 2 | 1986, October 13 | [[Erie County Holding Center|Erie County Correction Facility]] | {{flag|USA}} |In 1986, at age 19, Matt was convicted and sentenced to a year in jail. The term was interrupted when Matt, taking advantage of a guard’s mistake, slipped out of his cell, scaled a 9-foot brick and metal wall topped with razor wire and hopped a freight train to his brother’s house in Tonawanda. Five days later, police officers found him brandishing an ax handle in his brother’s apartment. |- | 2015, June 6 | [[Clinton Correctional Facility]] | {{flag|USA}} | On June 6, 2015, inmates Richard Matt and David Sweat, both serving sentences for murder, [[2015 Clinton Correctional Facility escape|escaped]] from the facility. A prison employee, Joyce Mitchell, was charged with aiding their escape. Matt was shot and killed by police on June 26, 2015. |- |rowspan=2|{{sortname|Joaquín Guzmán|Loera}} (born 1954 or 1957) |rowspan=2| 2 | 2001, January 19 | "Puente Grande" Federal Center for Social Rehabilitation No. 2 | {{flag|MEX}} | On 19 January 2001, Francisco "El Chito" Camberos Rivera, a prison guard, opened Guzmán's electronically operated cell door, and Guzmán got in a laundry cart that maintenance worker Javier Camberos rolled through several doors and eventually out the front door. He was then transported in the trunk of a car driven by Camberos out of the town. The escape allegedly cost Guzmán $2.5 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amw.com/fugitives/case.cfm?id=25154|title=Guzmán Escapes|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121025095718/http://www.amw.com/fugitives/case.cfm?id=25154|archivedate=2012-10-25|df=}}</ref> |- | 2015, July 11 | "Altiplano" [[Federal Social Readaptation Center No. 1]] | {{flag|MEX}} | In his second escape from the prison, he escaped through a tunnel leading from the shower area to a home construction site 1.5 km (0.93 mi) away in a Santa Juanita neighborhood. The tunnel was 1.7 m (5.7 ft) tall and 75 cm (29.5 in) in width. It was equipped with artificial light, air conditioning, and high-quality construction materials.<ref name=reformafuga>{{cite news|last1=Martínez|first1=César|title=Escapó 'Chapo' por túnel de 1.5 km|url=http://www.reforma.com/aplicacioneslibre/articulo/default.aspx?id=589370&md5=fff66622e1862e9b295ee653b4ff13be&ta=0dfdbac11765226904c16cb9ad1b2efe#ixzz3fggfMYlD|publisher=[[Reforma]]|date=12 July 2015|language=Spanish}}</ref> |- |rowspan=2|{{sortname|Frank|Abagnale}} (born 1948) |rowspan=2| 2 | | British VC-10 airliner (while deporting) | {{flag|USA}} | |- | 1971, April | [[Federal Detention Center]], Atlanta, Georgia | {{flag|USA}} | |- |{{sortname|Philip Andrew|Marshall}} (born 19??) | 5 | 2018, February 19 | [[Bedford County Jail]], Shelbyville, Tennessee | {{flag|USA}} | Escaped six times over the years. |}
==See also== * [[Prison escape]] * [[List of helicopter prison escapes]] * [[List of prisoner-of-war escapes]]

{{Redirect|Royal wedding|the 1951 MGM musical|Royal Wedding}} {{Unreferenced|date=October 2018}} [[File:The marriage procession of Dara Shikoh - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|The [[Mughal emperors|Mughal Emperor]] [[Shah Jahan]] attends the marriage procession of his eldest son [[Dara Shikoh]]. Mughal-Era [[fireworks]] were utilized to brighten the night throughout the wedding ceremony.]]
A '''royal wedding''' is a [[marriage ceremony]] involving members of a [[royal family]]. Weddings involving senior members of the royal family are often seen as important occasions of state and attract significant national and international attention. The following is a list of notable royal weddings:
== 19th century == ===Russian Empire=== * [[Wedding of Nicholas II and Alexandra Feodorovna|26 November 1895]]: [[Nicholas II of Russia|Nicholas II]], the last [[Emperor of All Russia|Emperor of Russia]], was married to [[Alexandra Feodorovna (Alix of Hesse)|Alexandra Feodorovna]] at the [[Grand Church of the Winter Palace]].
===United Kingdom=== * [[Wedding of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha|10 February 1840]]: [[Queen Victoria]], only daughter of [[Prince Edward, Duke of Kent and Strathearn]], and successor of [[William IV of the United Kingdom|King William IV]], was married to [[Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha]], Duke of Saxony, at the [[Chapel Royal]], [[St James's Palace]]. * [[Wedding of Prince George, Duke of York, and Princess Mary of Teck|6 July 1893]]: [[George V|Prince George, Duke of York]], second son of King [[Edward VII]], was married to [[Mary of Teck|Princess Victoria Mary of Teck]] at the [[Chapel Royal]], [[St James's Palace]].
== 20th century == ===Belgium=== * [[Wedding of Prince Philippe and Mathilde d'Udekem d'Acoz|4 December 1999]]: [[Philippe of Belgium|Prince Philippe, Duke of Brabant]], eldest child and successor to [[Albert II of Belgium|King Albert II]], was married to [[Mathilde d'Udekem d'Acoz]] at the [[Cathedral of St. Michael and St. Gudula]].
===Greece=== * [[Wedding of Pavlos, Crown Prince of Greece, and Marie-Chantal Miller|1 July 1995]]: [[Pavlos, Crown Prince of Greece]], eldest son and second child of [[Constantine II of Greece|King Constantine II]], was married to [[Marie-Chantal, Crown Princess of Greece|Marie-Chantal Miller]].
===United Kingdom=== * [[Wedding of Prince Albert, Duke of York, and Lady Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon|26 April 1923]]: [[George VI|Prince Albert, Duke of York]], second son of King [[George V]] and successor to [[Edward VIII|King Edward VIII]], was married to [[Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother|Lady Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon]] at [[Westminster Abbey]]. * [[Wedding of Princess Elizabeth and Philip Mountbatten|20 November 1947]]: [[Elizabeth II|Princess Elizabeth]], eldest daughter and successor of King [[George VI]], was married to [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh|Lieutenant Philip Mountbatten]] at [[Westminster Abbey]]. * [[Wedding of Princess Anne and Mark Phillips|14 November 1973]]: [[Anne, Princess Royal|Princess Anne]], only daughter of Queen [[Elizabeth II]], was married to [[Mark Phillips|Captain Mark Phillips]] at [[Westminster Abbey]]. * [[Wedding of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer|29 July 1981]]: [[Charles, Prince of Wales]], eldest son of Queen [[Elizabeth II]] and heir apparent, was married to [[Diana, Princess of Wales|Lady Diana Spencer]] at [[St Paul's Cathedral]]. * [[Wedding of Prince Andrew and Sarah Ferguson|23 July 1986]]: [[Prince Andrew, Duke of York]], second son of Queen [[Elizabeth II]], was married to [[Sarah, Duchess of York|Sarah Ferguson]] at [[Westminster Abbey]]. * [[Wedding of Prince Edward and Sophie Rhys-Jones|19 June 1999]]: [[Prince Edward, Earl of Wessex]], youngest son of Queen [[Elizabeth II]], was married to [[Sophie, Countess of Wessex|Sophie Rhys-Jones]] at [[St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle]].
== 21st century == ===Bhutan=== * [[Wedding of Jigme Khesar Namgyel Wangchuck and Jetsun Pema|13 October 2011]]: [[Jigme Khesar Namgyel Wangchuck]], King of Bhutan, was married to [[Jetsun Pema]] at the [[Punakha Dzong]] in [[Punakha|Punakha, Bhutan]].
===Denmark=== * [[Wedding of Frederik, Crown Prince of Denmark, and Mary Donaldson|14 May 2004]]: [[Frederik, Crown Prince of Denmark|Crown Prince Frederik of Denmark]], eldest son of [[Margrethe II of Denmark]] and heir apparent, was married to [[Mary, Crown Princess of Denmark|Mary Elizabeth Donaldson]] at the [[Church of Our Lady (Copenhagen)|Church of Our Lady]], [[Copenhagen]].
===Luxembourg=== * [[Wedding of Guillaume, Hereditary Grand Duke of Luxembourg, and Countess Stéphanie de Lannoy|20 October 2012]]: [[Guillaume, Hereditary Grand Duke of Luxembourg|Hereditary Grand Duke Guillaume]], eldest son of [[Henri, Grand Duke of Luxembourg]] and heir apparent, was married to [[Stéphanie, Hereditary Grand Duchess of Luxembourg|Countess Stephanie de Lannoy]] at the [[Notre-Dame Cathedral, Luxembourg]].
===Monaco=== * [[Wedding of Albert II, Prince of Monaco, and Charlene Wittstock|1 July 2011]]: [[Albert II, Prince of Monaco|Albert II]], [[Monarchy of Monaco|Sovereign Prince]] of Monaco, was married to [[Charlene, Princess of Monaco|Charlene Lynette Wittstock]] at the [[Prince's Palace of Monaco]].
===Norway=== * [[Wedding of Haakon, Crown Prince of Norway, and Mette-Marit Tjessem Høiby|25 August 2001]]: [[Haakon, Crown Prince of Norway|Crown Prince Haakon of Norway]], only son of King [[Harald V of Norway]] and heir apparent, was married to [[Mette-Marit, Crown Princess of Norway|Mette-Marit Tjessem Høiby]] at the [[Oslo Cathedral]].
===Spain=== * [[Wedding of Prince Felipe and Letizia Ortiz|22 May 2004]]: [[Felipe VI of Spain|Prince Felipe of Asturias]], only son of [[Juan Carlos I of Spain]], was married to [[Queen Letizia of Spain|Letizia Ortiz]] at the [[Almudena Cathedral]] at [[Royal Palace of Madrid]], [[Madrid]].
===Sweden=== * [[Wedding of Victoria, Crown Princess of Sweden, and Daniel Westling|19 June 2010]]: [[Victoria, Crown Princess of Sweden|Crown Princess Victoria of Sweden]], eldest daughter and heir apparent of [[Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden|Carl XVI Gustaf, King of Sweden]], was married to [[Prince Daniel, Duke of Västergötland|Daniel Westling]] at the [[Stockholm Cathedral]]. * [[Wedding of Princess Madeleine and Christopher O'Neill|8 June 2013]]: [[Princess Madeleine, Duchess of Hälsingland and Gästrikland|Princess Madeleine of Sweden]], youngest child of [[Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden|Carl XVI Gustaf, King of Sweden]], was married to [[Christopher O'Neill]] at the [[Stockholm Palace]] Church. * [[Wedding of Prince Carl Philip and Sofia Hellqvist|13 June 2015]]: [[Prince Carl Philip, Duke of Värmland|Prince Carl Philip]], Only son of [[Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden|Carl XVI Gustaf, King of Sweden]], was married to [[Sofia Hellqvist]] at the [[Stockholm Palace]] Church.
===Tonga=== * [[Wedding of Crown Prince Tupoutoʻa ʻUlukalala and Sinaitakala Fakafanua|12 July 2012]]: [[Tupoutoʻa ʻUlukalala]], Crown Prince of Tonga, was married to [[Sinaitakala Fakafanua]] at the Centennial Church in [[Nukuʻalofa]], Tonga.
===United Kingdom=== * [[Wedding of Prince Charles and Camilla Parker Bowles|9 April 2005]]: [[Charles, Prince of Wales]], eldest son of Queen [[Elizabeth II]] and heir apparent, was married to [[Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall|Camilla Parker Bowles]] at [[Windsor Guildhall]]. * [[Wedding of Prince William and Catherine Middleton|29 April 2011]]: [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge]], second grandson of Queen [[Elizabeth II]], elder son of [[Charles, Prince of Wales]] and [[Lady Diana Spencer]] is second in line to the throne, was married to [[Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge|Catherine Middleton]] at [[Westminster Abbey]]. * [[Wedding of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle|19 May 2018]]: [[Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex]], third grandson of Queen [[Elizabeth II]], younger son of [[Charles, Prince of Wales]] and [[Lady Diana Spencer]] is sixth in line to the throne, was married to [[Meghan, Duchess of Sussex|Meghan Markle]] at [[St George's Chapel]], [[Windsor Castle]]. * [[Wedding of Princess Eugenie and Jack Brooksbank|12 October 2018]]: [[Princess Eugenie]], third granddaughter of Queen [[Elizabeth II]], younger daughter of [[Prince Andrew, Duke of York]] and [[Sarah Ferguson]] is ninth in line to the throne, was married to [[Jack Brooksbank]] at [[St George's Chapel]], [[Windsor Castle]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.britishpathe.com/workspace.php?id=10826&view=list The Royal Weddings Collection - Archived newsreels of British Royal Weddings] *[http://www.itnsource.com/specials/royalengagement Royal wedding footage]
{{Wedding}}
